posts.name: Eric Ward
posts.cooked:
Github Desktop VSCode Extension CLI (git bash) Other (comment) 0 voters

Github Desktop VSCode Extension CLI (git bash) Other (comment)

Github Desktop

VSCode Extension

CLI (git bash)

Other (comment)

0 voters

0 voters

0 voters

Personally, I use the CLI tool because that’s what I’ve always used and it’s what I use at work, but I’ve met people in professional contexts who always use a frontend. In the past, I’ve tried teaching Github Desktop to new members because to me that seems easier than teaching a CLI, but the issue is that I’m not a power-user of the front-ends, so whenever someone’s local repo gets screwed up I don’t know how to fix it unless I use the CLI and inevitably I just tell them commands to run.

Should I just bite the bullet and become an expert in using a frontend, or is it better to just try and teach the CLI from the get-go since ultimately that’s the most powerful tool of the 3. I’m curious what setup has worked well for other teams.

posts.name: AllenGregoryIV
posts.cooked:
Github desktop is primary and VSCode extensions is also used sometimes especially for just switching branches, etc.

If we have to do something complicated I’ll normally figure out the CLI stuff for the students. Sometimes we have a student that already knows git CLI but we don’t teach it.

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked:
We use a mix of tools, but the primary one for most coders (we only have 3) is the VSCode extension as that covers the basic needs well.

bathtubed:

Should I just bite the bullet and become an expert in using a frontend

IMO, you wouldn’t need to change and “become an expert” in using the tooling the students are using; you just need to know enough to tell them “when you want to change branches, do this; when you want to see what branch you’re on, do this; to commit, do this; to push, do this.” No bullet-biting; it’ll take you longer to read this CD thread than to learn the handful of common gestures.

Learing why (and when ) to use a branch is harder and more valuable than learning how in the tooling.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
We are the weirdos who use Git Extensions

Git Extensions is a standalone UI tool for managing Git repositories

But it’s just a tool. Consistency is good at first to teach concepts, but after that it’s whatever comes most naturally.

I am an advocate for using some graphical tool for git to start. The tree is hard to visualize at first.

link_counts.title: Git Extensions | Git Extensions is a standalone UI tool for managing Git repositories

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: The VSCode GUI is easy enough to understand. Open the command palette, and type in the thing you wanna do, like “git push” and it’ll come up and you just hit enter and it does it.

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
The one thing I will say about VScodes GUI is make sure your students pay close attention to all pop ups and bottom corner notifications. It’s very easy to close one in a hurry and miss vital info. Also if for some reason you have files not in your .gitignore but also not tracked VScode will prompt to auto add all untracked files. This is annoying when you have alternate or archived versions of code files you want to keep local only to keep your teams repo clean.

Some of this is just git management preferences and me being nitpicky. But it is a limiting factor that I don’t see happen as often with the GitHub desktop application. Both let you visually checkbox what items you want added to the repo, but VScode then asks you to add all anyways if you leave stuff behind. GitHub desktop just assumes that’s what you intended.

Maybe I’m crazy? But I’ve seen it happen numerous times when bringing people up to speed in VSCode.

posts.name: Jeffrey Davis
posts.cooked: I must be getting old. Why would they need to learn another tool when Git is already good?

posts.name: Eric Ward
posts.cooked:
Doing basic stuff is whatever, the problem is when they make a mistake and trap themselves in a corner.

Either some nightmarish merge conflict, or they want to uncommit some file, or break up a commit. These require more complex control than just “stage, commit, change branch, push.”

When this happens I usually just fire up the terminal and run a bunch of checkouts, resets, and rebases, but should I be instead learning to fix these things in their chosen git interface so I can teach them how to fix things?

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked:
Fix the random screw-ups on the command line (or however you are most comfortable).

Let the kids use the normal workflow in their preferred tooling. (The beauty of git is multiple “porcelains” work over the same underlying pipes.)

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
For us, primarily because not all students who come in are adept at command line, or visualizing abstract concepts from textual descriptions.

While those students should overcome those limitations, I’m not about to hold up robot development for them.

GUI’s are a tool, just like command line interfaces and punchcards. Use the tool that not only is right for the job at hand, but also is known enough to the wielder to get the job done.

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked:
Establishing a consistent process is probably more important than the particulars of how a student interacts with git (GUI, terminal etc).

For example, our team has a master branch, which contains known working code only. A develop branch, where things are merged together for integration testing and staging for the master branch. Then we create branches for each subsystem (drive, shooter, intake, climber etc), where students do the work for that branch. Those branches are kept updated by rebasing onto develop. Once a student is done with their work, the student will merge their code into develop. The software lead is then responsible for periodically merging develop into master, and tagging versions.

We also typically create a branch from the latest tag in master for every event we go to, making it easier to keep track of the changes that were made for an event, and isolating them, in case some of those changes are jank.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
bathtubed:

Either some nightmarish merge conflict, or they want to uncommit some file, or break up a commit. These require more complex control than just “stage, commit, change branch, push.”

If that doesn't fix it, git.txt contains the phone number of a friend of mine who understands git. Just wait through a few minutes of 'It's really pretty simple, just think of branches as...' and eventually you'll learn the commands that will fix everything.

posts.name: Sam Carlberg
posts.cooked:
GitKraken for my team. The graphical branch view and the commit and conflict editors are so much better than trying to do it all In the CLI for students who have never used git before. Much easier to deal with while also dealing with everything that goes into build season

I haven’t used the GitHub client since its initial release, and sublime merge is a little less graphical (can’t drag and drop branches to merge, rebase, or push, for instance). But my focus was on students who’re also learning how to code and learn WPILib and its tools, so the low barrier to entry was GitKraken’s most appealing point

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked: We use the VS Code integration (not technically an extension). This covers the basic operations of stage, commit, push, pull, etc, while allowing programmers to review changes and fix merge conflicts in the same UI they program in.

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
We use a combination

VS Code’s native git tools

the Git Graph vscode extension for better visualizing commit history and the merge tree

command line

I prefer to ensure they have the git fundamentals down first (ie, what the magical incantations really do), and split things out into topic branches which avoid most issues. Once students get through the basics, and get their first merge down, they’ll rarely run into a need for more help.

VSCode + git graph do a good job here; This combination is excellent for viewing your git tree, commit log, and setting up new commits.

We completely avoid “automagical” tools that wrap git commands with more complex scripts (like “sync” buttons), or rename the operations. I’ve found these generally don’t reduce the need to learn what git is actually doing, and greatly add to the number of weird git things happening in your repo.

posts.name: Tal Moshel
posts.cooked:
For us what works best is: First we teach newbies the major functions of the Git CLI , this is in order for them to understand the basics and the steps required for most of what they’ll do. Later when they start working on their projects we let them teach themselves the Git Extension for VSCode .

This way the both UNDERSTAND everything they do, but also work comfortably.
